Hi Phil,

We can do what you suggested which would probably work, although still violates their TOS, so not advisable. There's no telling if they would catch on to this and completely remove your access to Adobe products. I have heard cases of this occurring, so we should tread carefully.

The only source for Adobe products is Adobe/Adobe Resellers, it's all Cloud based now so the products don't work without the subscription licenses which are tightly controlled by Adobe. With Adobe, things have been moving towards a point in which you can only use their products in the way they dictate.

Our typical setup is that each employee has a license assigned for whichever products they use. I believe the options we have are to either do it this way (recommended), or the way you suggest in which users share a license.

Let me know if you have any questions, thanks.

Blumira has detected Azure: Entra ID Global Admin Role Assignment for Click Engineering on 2025-05-06 12:29PM CDT and triggered action Create Priority 1 Suspect for Responders.

Analysis:

A Global Administrator Role has been assigned to the user or group ibabcock@clickeng.com in your Entra ID Directory in the tenant 40da309f-5eba-49d0-b2e9-194ce53b78dc.

A Global Administrator has full permissions over the entire Azure tenant, similar to a Domain Administrator in on premise Active Directory. This role should be protected and access limited to as few individuals as possible to prevent abuse of these permissions.

Please note, this detection excludes assignments by Privileged Identity Management (PIM) and Granular delegated admin permissions (GDAP). If you would like to monitor PIM/GDAP assignments enable the detection "Azure: Entra ID Global Admin Role Assignment by PIM/GDAP" from the Detection Rules page under Settings.

comments.subject: Contact
comments.body:
Morning Jomaree,

I’ve been working through it for a little while this morning, but it looks like I’m having the same issue come up again. Could you log in and take a look?

Thank you,
Ryan

From: Jomaree Lawsin <support@cloudavize.com>
Sent: Tuesday, May 6, 2025 3:56 PM
To: Ryan Jackson <ryan.jackson@artizin.com>
Cc: Collin Tasi <Collin.tasi@mavconcepts.com>; Ryan Jackson <ryan.jackson@mavconcepts.com>
Subject: IT Ticket - WMI Provider Host CPU usage (message id: 94575740)

comments.subject: Update
comments.body:
Hi Ryan,

Anytime! I did notice earlier that one of the DYMO processes (`DYMO.WebApi.Win.Host.exe`) showed up in the WMI activity logs. It’s possible that the DYMO software is polling hardware status in the background, which might be contributing to the higher CPU usage from the WMI Provider Host.

If the issue pops up again, one thing we can try is temporarily unplugging the label printer and closing the DYMO software to see if that brings the CPU usage down. That would help confirm if it’s part of the cause.

Let me know how things go or if you’d like me to assist with testing that further.

Thank you,
Jomaree

comments.subject: Contact
comments.body:
Thank you Jomaree, I really appreciate your help!

Should I try to troubleshoot detaching one of the usb drives I have if the problem reoccurs? I currently have my dymo label printer attached via USB and in my USB-C port I have my Type-C USB Hub for my monitors and internet connection.

Thank you,
Ryan

[embedded image]

Ryan Jackson / Project Manager

O 972 934 5784 x110 / C 817 663 5285

[ARTIZIN.COM](https://www.artizin.com/)

[embedded image] [embedded image]

A Maverick Concepts Company

From: Jomaree Lawsin <support@cloudavize.com>
Sent: Tuesday, May 6, 2025 3:20 PM
To: Ryan Jackson <ryan.jackson@artizin.com>
Cc: Collin Tasi <Collin.tasi@mavconcepts.com>; Ryan Jackson <ryan.jackson@mavconcepts.com>
Subject: IT Ticket - WMI Provider Host CPU usage (message id: 94575740)

comments.subject: Update
comments.body:
Hi Ryan,

I took a look and confirmed that the WMI Provider Host process (`WmiPrvSE.exe`) was using a large amount of CPU, similar to what you experienced before.

To help reduce the impact, I applied a script that lowers the process’s priority automatically when it runs. This should help keep things more stable during regular use.

We’ll continue monitoring, and if the issue comes back or worsens, the next step would be to trace what specifically is triggering WMI to spike — which can sometimes be caused by third-party software or drivers.

Feel free to let me know if the performance improves or if you notice any unusual behavior.

Thank you,
Jomaree

comments.subject: Initial Issue
comments.body:
I am having issues on my machine with it being very slow. The best description I can give is that it becomes jumpy as if the machine is dropping frame rate. It will do this when I am running AutoCAD primarily but it occasionally happens in Adobe Illustrator as well. This issue doesn't happen all the time but it is often enough to where something needs to be addressed.

Steps to recreate issue:
Open AutoCAD
Open file
A:\Ordant\Copper Spring Solutions\2500\WIP\2500_CSS_Mead Center.dwg
As the file starts to open move the cursor around to see the jump.

With that said after the file fully opens it tends to go away but this was the only way I could recreate my problem repeatably. Multitasking different programs also makes the problem occur. Just watching the task manager as I am working it seems like there are a lot of background tasks that keeps occurring that I have no clue what they are related to so I am hesitant to end them. These tasks will spike CPU usage.

If you all could look into this after hours I would appreciate it. I am typically in at 8 AM CT and out after 5 PM CT.

Thanks in advance for the help,
Travis

comments.subject: Update
comments.body:
Hi Garison,

The main issue was related to VLAN tagging after the switch lost its settings. Specifically, on the 142-NET-101 switch, port 1/0/6 (which connects to the 2B-NET-111 switch) did not have the HSLAB VLAN tagged. Similarly, on the 2B-NET-111 switch, port 2/0/41 (where the RM109 AP is connected) was also missing the HSLAB VLAN tag.

Also, I remember I rebooted the RM109 AP as part of the process.

Let me know if you have any other questions!

Thank you,
Jorenzo

Hello Cody,

You may remember the work you did for us to get the AP in our HS computer lab to have a local-only SSID that would allow us to use the snap drop utility for local WIFI file transfer without access to the internet.

We are experiencing issues with that setup now. We believe it is since the power outage and could be related to the switch losing settings, but it’s possible the issue predates that and is unrelated.

Essentially we are finding that when the HSLAB ap template is applied to an ap, it stops accepting connections, even for non HSLAP ssids (CC10 for example). From the vWLAN side, the devices appear to connected but the devices show no internet and on IOS the loading spinner never ends and the device never fully connects to WiFi.

We have confirmed that the AP hardware is fine by switching it over to other AP Templates and everything works.

Thanks in advance for your help on this! We would happy to set up unit for you to test with an AP with HSLAB ap template applied nearby.

comments.subject: Automation
comments.body: Automation Ticket Priority - Normal ran on this ticket. Actions: Change Priority to 2 Normal

comments.subject: Initial Issue
comments.body:
[embedded image](https://www.blumira.com/)

Suspect | P3 | Microsoft 365: Suspicious Inbox Rule Creation @ The Patel Law Group

Blumira has detected Microsoft 365: Suspicious Inbox Rule Creation for The Patel Law Group on 2025-05-05 12:56PM CDT and triggered action Create Priority 3 Suspect for Responders.

Analysis:

The user nsaxena@patellegal.com created a new mail filtering inbox rule in Microsoft 365. Inbox rule creation is often the next step taken by threat actors after initially compromising the email account. These rules typically have a goal of hiding activity performed while the account is compromised, such as removing email from sent folders or deleting all incoming messages to the victim’s inbox.

comments.subject: Update
comments.body:
Hi Josh,

Good morning!

Just following up on our troubleshooting results from yesterday. We still need to exhaust all procedures before processing the replacement. The last one would be a power hard reset with procedures below.

1. Disconnect the power cable from the desktop.
2. Disconnect all devices or devices like USB drives, printer cables, and media card.
3. Press and hold the power button down for 30 to 35 seconds to drain residual power and reset the Real-Time Clock (RTC).
4. Connect the power cable to the desktop.
5. Turn on the desktop.
Please note that the reset process is aborted if you interrupt the power or hold the power button down for less than 30 seconds or more than 35 seconds. You can always try the reset again.

Let me know the results when you get the chance.

Thank you,
Michael

comments.subject: Update
comments.body:
Hi Josh,

Just following up on this issue. When you get the chance, kindly please perform the following steps to hard reset the computer power supply.

1. Disconnect the power cable from the desktop.
2. Disconnect all devices or devices like USB drives, printer cables, and media card.
3. Press and hold the power button down for 30 to 35 seconds to drain residual power and reset the Real-Time Clock (RTC).
4. Connect the power cable to the desktop.
5. Turn on the desktop.
Please note that the reset process is aborted if you interrupt the power or hold the power button down for less than 30 seconds or more than 35 seconds. You can always try the reset again.

Please let us know of the result so we can process the replacement immediately.

Thank you,
Michael

comments.subject: Update
comments.body:
Hi Josh,

Good morning! This is Michael from Cloudavize, supporting ResProp for IT management.

We're sorry that you are having this power issue. Let's go over to the following steps to narrow down and resolve this.

1. Ensure the power outlet is working by plugging in another device to confirm it has power.
If you're using a power strip, Automatic Voltage Regulators, or surge protector, check if it has a reset button and press it. Alternatively, try plugging the desktops directly into the wall outlet.

2. Inspect and verify that the power cables are securely connected to both the desktops and the power outlet.
Check for any visible damage to the cables, such as fraying or cuts. If damaged, replace them with a new one.

3. Test the Power Supply Units (PSUs)
A power surge during the outage may have damaged the PSU in your desktops. To test:
Look for any lights on the motherboard or fans spinning when you press the power button.
If there are no signs of life, the PSU may need to be replaced.

4. If the outlet is damaged, try plugging the desktops into a different outlet in another room.

Let me know the results if there are any improvements.

Thank you,
Michael

Michael
